title: The Ten

one.title: _Love_ yourself the way you are
one.text: Be your own best friend. Love yourself and don’t compare yourself to others.

two.title: Put your phone _down_ and get lost in the moment.
two.text: Don’t allow your phone to take you out of the moment. Enjoy your life with good friends.

three.title: Try something _new_.
three.text: Step out of your comfort zone and experience new things. Life is full of exciting opportunities.

four.title: Get enough _sleep_, _eat_ well and _exercise_.
four.text: Take good care of yourself. Physical health supports mental well-being.

five.title: Learn to say _no_.
five.text: You are the boss of your own life and you don’t need to please others. Sometimes no is the right answer.

six.title: Have a _positive_ mindset and enjoy.
six.text: Direct your mind in a positive direction. Be thankful and enjoy what you have.

seven.title: Follow your _dreams_.
seven.text: Don’t give up on your dreams when things don’t go your way. The more resilience, the sweeter the victory.

eight.title: Be a loyal _friend_.
eight.text: Be there for your friends when they’re going through a hard time. True friendship is one of the most valuable gifts of life.

nine.title: Don’t be afraid to make mistakes, _learn_ from your experiences.
nine.text: Keep trying and accept challenges. Mistakes are a natural part of life.

ten.title: Tell someone and seek _help_ if you don’t feel well.
ten.text: The first step towards feeling better is always telling someone. When a problem is put into words, the solution is around the corner.

about.title: About Útmeða
about.content: Geðhjálp and The Red Cross Helpline 1717 jointly run the preventice project Útmeð’a. The aim of the project is to promote improved public health by encouraging people, with a special emphasis on young people, to express their mental well-being and seek professional assistance when needed. The project is urgent, considering that between 500 and 600 people seek help at clinics and hospitals in Iceland due to self-harm following anxiety every year. Suicide is the most common cause of death for young men in Iceland.
